snippet: A report by the United Nations predicts that only four of the 30 largest cities — New York, Los Angeles, Tokyo and Osaka, Japan — will be in high-income nations in 16 years.
abstract: Floyd Norris Off The Charts column examines United Nations report on the estimated population of global cities by 2030; notes results found that only four of the 30 largest will be in high-income nations, with a large number located in tropical zones; observes countries are urbanizing at uneven levels of development, raising questions of sustainability.
lead_paragraph: A report by the United Nations predicts that only four of the 30 largest cities — New York, Los Angeles, Tokyo and Osaka, Japan — will be in high-income nations in 16 years.

headline.print_headline: For Biggest Cities of 2030, Look Toward the Tropics
headline.main: For Biggest Cities of 2030, Look Toward the Tropics
